name: Excess Mortality Data – OWID (2022)
title: Excess Mortality Data – OWID (2022)
description:
All-cause mortality data is from the Human Mortality Database (HMD) Short-term Mortality Fluctuations project and the World Mortality Dataset (WMD). Both sources are updated weekly.

We do not use the data from some countries in WMD because they fail to meet the following data quality criteria: 1) at least three years of historical data; and 2) data published either weekly or monthly. The full list of excluded countries and reasons for exclusion can be found in this spreadsheet: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1JPMtzsx-smO3_K4ReK_HMeuVLEzVZ71qHghSuAfG788/edit?usp=sharing.

For a full list of source information (i.e., HMD or WMD) country by country, see: https://ourworldindata.org/excess-mortality-covid#source-information-country-by-country.

We calculate P-scores using the reported deaths data from HMD and WMD and the projected deaths for 2020–2022 from WMD (which we use for all countries and regions, including for deaths broken down by age group). The P-score is the percentage difference between the reported number of weekly or monthly deaths in 2020–2022 and the projected number of deaths for the same period based on previous years.

We calculate the number of weekly deaths for the United Kingdom by summing the weekly deaths from England & Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland.

For important issues and caveats to understand when interpreting excess mortality data, see our excess mortality page at https://ourworldindata.org/excess-mortality-covid.

For a more detailed description of the HMD data, including week date definitions, the coverage (of individuals, locations, and time), whether dates are for death occurrence or registration, the original national source information, and important caveats, see the HMD metadata file at https://www.mortality.org/Public/STMF_DOC/STMFmetadata.pdf.

For a more detailed description of the WMD data, including original source information, see their GitHub page at https://github.com/akarlinsky/world_mortality.

sources.name: Human Mortality Database (2022), World Mortality Dataset (2022)
sources.additionalInfo:

sources.dataPublishedBy: The Human Mortality Database, The World Mortality Dataset
sources.dataPublisherSource: National civil registration and vital statistics offices

fields.name: p_avg_all_ages
fields.description: P-scores using 5-year average baseline for all ages
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Excess mortality P-scores, 5-year average baseline, all ages", "unit": "%", "zeroDay": "2020-01-01", "shortUnit": "%", "yearIsDay": true, "includeInTable": true, "numDecimalPlaces": 0}

fields.name: p_avg_15_64
fields.description: P-scores using projected baseline for ages 15–64

fields.description: P-scores using projected baseline for ages 65–74

fields.name: p_avg_75_84
fields.description: P-scores using projected baseline for ages 75–84

fields.name: p_avg_85p
fields.description: P-scores using projected baseline for ages 85 and above

fields.name: time
fields.description: The week or month number in the year

fields.description: Denotes whether the “time” column values are weekly or monthly

fields.description: P-scores using 5-year average baseline for ages 0–14

fields.description: Projected number of weekly or monthly deaths from all causes for all ages for 2020–2022

fields.name: excess_proj_all_ages
fields.description: The number of excess deaths; calculated as reported deaths minus projected deaths

fields.name: cum_excess_proj_all_ages
fields.description: The cumulative number of excess deaths; cumulated starting 1 January 2020

fields.name: cum_proj_deaths_all_ages
fields.description: The cumulative number of projected deaths; cumulated starting 1 January 2020

fields.description: Cumulative P-scores using projected baseline for all ages

fields.description: The cumulative number of excess deaths per million people in the population; cumulated starting 1 January 2020

fields.description: The number of excess deaths per million people in the population; calculated as reported deaths minus projected deaths

fields.description: The reported number of weekly or monthly deaths from all causes for all ages in 2022.
